name: how do you Do It?
description: "how do you Do It?" puts players in the role of an 11-year-old girl whose mother has just stepped out for an errand. The girl immediately grabs her dolls and furtively attempts to figure out how sex works using these plastic surrogates.

A kid who just saw Titanic uses her dolls to try to recreate the sex scene with hot scissoring action. That's the whole game. It's two minutes.  Pros:  *Make the sex with hot scissoring action. *You can turn them around and crash them into each other head first. This also counts as doing a sex. *At the end of the game, a screen tells you how many times you've been known to have been involved in sex-doing-activities. * The plasticman sexmaking game is free.  Cons: *Steam overlay doesn't work so I don't have any screenshots of the doll sex. *Steam overlay doesn't work so I don't have screenshottable video game proof that I have probably done a sex.  Summary: Rename this game Do a Sex: Human Procreation.

The premise here is that this kid just saw Titanic and is trying to figure out what the hell happened in the car.  She directly references the sex scene in Titanic in her little speech bubbles as you're flailing the dolls around.  If you weren't a kid when Titanic came out, you miss out on half the joke, but it's still pretty hilarious to flail the dolls around wildly and get a message after about 30 seconds to a minute saying how many times you might have made the dolls have sex. Possibly. Perhaps.

This game is a masterpiece of modern game technology and storytelling. The game opens on a heartbreaking scene of a mother abandoning her only child. You, the child, must find a way to cope with the soul-eating emptiness left in your heart by the sudden disappearance of your mother. Throughout hours of play, I have found myself really getting pulled into the plot of this game, exploring my childhood memories, and expanding my worldview. The graphics are stunning, and it is almost unbelievable that this game was created by a team as small as four people. I'm looking forward to the next piece of innovative gaming from these folks. Overall, I give this game a 6/9. Would play again.

'A game that seems to shimmer with a profound and galvanising lucidity, a colossus that bestrides all other genres and archetypes to forge its own mark upon the industry forever.'   7/10

The hours spent playing this masterpiece were the perfect encapsulation of why videogaming is such a favourite waste of time for so many of us. Thrilling, terrifying, moving, confusing, amusing, compelling, and very very dark. HOW DO YOU DO IT? isn't simply the sign of gaming realising its true cinematic potential, but one where a game straddles so many entertainment art forms so expertly that it's the best demonstration yet how flexible this medium can be. It's no longer just another shooter wrapped up in a pretty game engine, but a story that exists and unfolds inside the most convincing and elaborate and artistic game world ever conceived.

This game has, by far, one of the greatest stories you will ever experience. And I would sex 227 more times.  The creators place you in a mediocre home. one large window in the front of the home, an average couch, family portrait, lamp. And it begins with your mother, gazing at you in discontent. She sports a rather dull purple blouse and a navy blue skirt. The real story hits you hard at this point. She seems to dissipate into thin air, appearing to drive away in a what looks to be an Audi or Mini Cooper. The young girl watches, waits, stares, looks, observes, sees, and any synonym thereof. She then shyfully, makes her way to her dolls. One male, one female. This is where you, the player, take control of this delectable, ripe little girl. The choice is yours, you smash and rotate dolls in an increasingly curious rush to discover how you 'do it.' The blonde thinks of the sex scene in the Titanic and things her Mimi has told her.  So very fascinating.  Then, her mother returns, which makes you question where she went in the first place. You immediately throw down the dolls and turn around blushing. The game promptly ends and tells you how many times you have had sex.  This game has truly opened my eyes in terms of story writing. I implore you to play this game for a minimum of 24 hours to truly experience how great this game is. It baffles you how much you can learn.

There was this moment. We all had it. Maybe age 9. Maybe age 11... maybe even 13 or 7 but golly, it was a rush. We had dolls, figurines, books, pictures.... sometimes just our minds and we wondered, how do you Do It? Do it... that thing that makes you... tingle... not itch but.... below and all over... what is it...  JUST DON'T GET CAUGHT!!!!! Or is Mom just acting like she didn't see you... Maybe you shuld try again...  This is the game... this is real life. This is a simulation of sexual curiosity. Do it to remind youself of how wonderous we all were at young ages.  Not to mention the Sim-like, 90's, video-game music... It'll bring back many memories for 90's kids. A wonderful tale about self discovery and exploration. It took me back to times when I was 11, I too had dolls and used them to learn about sexual intercourse. Shortly after I began to think about things more sexually. I noticed girls in my class being pretty, rather than being icky and having 'cooties.' One girl took a certain liking to me. We began to hang out outside of school and one day she told me to take off my pants. I wasn't sure why but I did it anyways. It was my first time getting a handjob. I told my friend, and he told my mom like a snitch. Police showed up at my school the next day and arrested my teacher. I miss Mrs. Lidner.  10/10 can't wait for the sequel

FUNDAMENTAL   very cute!  although you might think you already know how to play this, you can't actually win.  it's more about enjoying a memory, the silliness of some of your unfortunate experiments, but mostly experimentation and role playing as a youngster defining for herself what sex is.  For a free game, it's an adorable but thought provoking little experience with a very nostalgic feel.  Note:  I'm not sure if this was intentional, but the rotation seems to happen randomly.   Suggestions:  to add more playability, there should be a click and drag poseability option & screen shot capability. And to add more depth to the concept, they should include all different types of dolls to choose from and use. therefore its true experimentation.

I am not going to joke about the subject or art. My problem with this is where it comes from. These are the group of people that want to remove anything 'game' related in games.. and instead put in public awareness messages. I support the need for Sexual Education, and I like when someone does something that supports it. If that was all there was, I would be fine with this 'game'. What bothers me is the winning a Indecade GAMES competition with something that flash video users embedded into websites 10 years ago. This is not the future of games, this is a huge throwback to the gaming scene. You want games as Art? Go play ICO or Flower, or see what real game art is and play a game that makes you thing and debate like Bioshock. There games industry is very diverse if you are willing to experience mutliple genres.   The content here is nothing more then a flash game. I am glad it was free, and I am in support of people that want to develop this... but it should never have been allowed to be called a game. There is no direction, no writing, no pacing, no leaderboards, no real score, no reply value. This is a joke to everyone expect a small group of people that believe games like this... should be allowed, and games like COD, Street Fighter, Bioshock, Assassin's Creed, you name it... should not be allowed.  I tested to see if the game has ANY 'gameplay' elements. How did it tally up the score at the end? Put the 2 dolls heads together and leave them there moving the s and w keys so it goes up and down... BAM 400 maybe sex? Its only about how long they touch, not how well they are setup, position or learning anything. This would never be rated as a game. This is a interactive Flash animation.  I played the game... all the way through... and it said I did not use the product long enough to write a review. (5 minutes) This is a 3 minute long 'game' that I had to play through 2 more times to get to 5 minuets played, and the time is not even based on my own ability or lack of, that is simply the TIME of the game. Seriously ashamed of the Indiecade.

this game owes me a new pair of sides.

This non-game wasn't worth the time I spent playing it, and anyone who says it's 'entertaining' has lived in a box their entire life. 'How do you do it?' should not be on Steam.  My thoughts as I played this game:  The mom must've stepped out to drive to the corner and back because she gets back from her 'errand' in 20 seconds flat.  The art is mediocre. (A poor representation of a 90's maxis style)  The soundtrack is bland elevator music that shall haunt my dreams until the day I die  Whoever green-lit this garbage should be forced to play 'how do you do it?' for all eternity.  The only saving grace of this entire... whatever this thing is... was the thought bubble, who's wit ran out after the short list of thoughts pourred from that air-headed twerp in a manner that could only be described as 'repetitive and annoying.'  If you do play this game, play it ONCE and then never play it again. Enjoy the 30 seconds of your life you'll never get back.
I'd rather sext than play this. Good bye.

SpaceZeal0t said it best, and I'm writing this to reinforce what (s)he said.  What a waste of time, money and emotional investment (in the form of trust) this was. Just watch a video of it on Youtube; that's all there is to do or see here.  I'm just glad it was released for free; otherwise I may have had my free time taken up by writing to the devs to get a refund.  1/10 because I had a brief laugh at how bad it was.   TL;DR: It could have been a F2P sex-ed game. A wasted opportunity.

Pros: promotes women in video games  cons: follows a CIS heteronormative narrative. (one 'female' and one 'male')  We need more games that promote strong independent women in video games,' how do you DO it?' is a step in the right direction, but we also need to promote LGBTQrsvp 90210 3.14159 equality.

I feel like this game is a joke that I wasn't in on. Like, one person proposed the idea that they use the afternoon to create a game with no point but had an unusual theme. Then, sit back and watch people discuss how 'powerful', 'artistic', 'daring', or 'important' it was, a la Andy Kaufman. But really, they could have done just that by creating a game where you were a 11 year old girl catching fire flies in a jar. Boom! Nastalgia! Plus, you could overlay some generic 'innocense of youth' nonsense and you'd still have a game with some sort of challenge and reward system. Dang...did I just fall into the trap by writing this review?  Don't play this game or they win.
After years of burying my childhood memories deep, deep inside, they come flooding back. Thanks devs. Now I have to remember the disturbed look on my grandma's face.
